data.title: Greeting word frequency list
data.solution:
import re

# Get the string
text = input().lower()

# Create the word frequency dictionary
word_frequency = {"hi":0,"hello":0,"how are you":0,"welcome":0}

# Match all the whole greeting words (so "welcomed" isn't counted but "welcome!" is)
greetings_matches = re.findall(r"(?i)\b(hi|hello|welcome|how are you)\b", text)

# Loop over all the matches and add 1 to the frequency counter of that word
for gm in greetings_matches:
    word_frequency[gm] += 1

# Sort the dictionary by value
word_frequency = sorted(word_frequency.items(), key=lambda x:x[1])[::-1]
index = 0
for word in word_frequency:
    if word[1]: # check if the value is greater than 0
        index += 1
        print(f'{index}. {word[0]}: {word[1]}')
data.statement:
You need to output a sorted list of greetings: {{hi}}/{{hello}}/{{how are you}}/{{welcome}}
that appear in the input. it will be sorted by the most frequent greetings from the list of greetings above being placed at the top, so the most frequent greeting would rank as number 1.
Each line output would have this structure:
<<[rank]{{.}} [greeting]{{: }}[number of occurrences]>>


<<IMPORTANT: >>
<<1.>> You have to check if the greeting is a separate word, For example the word {{Hindi}} doesn't count as {{hi}}.
<<2.>> The greetings and counts are case-insensitive, which means: {{Hi}} also counts as {{hi}}.
<<3.>> Incase of a tie you should sort the list with the priority being: {{welcome}}, then {{how are you}}, then {{hello}} and lastly {{hi}}.
<<4.>> Greetings and words might not always be separated with a space they could also be like this: "{{Hi}}, man!" so that {{hi}} should count.
<<5.>> Don't include the greeting if it has 0 occurrences in the input.
